field_edited_text.value:
The Rouse Company

RN

Galleria at Harborplace - Rouse Co., Hotel, shopping arcade, office and parking, 1986/87

































































A ey

parking spaces in several locations as
demand increases. Further, the opening of
the first leg of the Baltimore subway should
improve access to the area and alleviate
some of the parking demand.

Adjacent residential communities of
Little Italy, Federal Hill, and Otterbein are
concerned about the impact on their neigh-
borhoods of heavily attended Inner Harbor
events. The City has developed residential
permit parking programs to limit the park-
ing impact and continues to work with the
neighborhoods to help them maintain their
residential atmosphere.

Finally, boating safety has become a
growing concern as more and more boat-
ers use the Inner Harbor for recreational
boating. As recreational boats are drawn to
the Inner Harbor’s basin they must navigate
through the country’s fourth most active
port. In the basin itself, a relatively small
water body, tourist boats, pleasure craft,
visiting ships, and paddle boats must com-
pete for limited space and right-of-way.
The Mayor’s Task Force on Boating Safety
was appointed in 1981 to develop ways of
dealing with potential conflicts. Added
police authority to deal with boating infrac-
tions has been implemented as a first step,
and the Task Force continues to address
the issues of speed, congestion and the
location and development of major marinas
to facilitate the growing interest of recrea-
tional boaters and allow the port to con-
tinue to grow.

o



Planned Development

If the past is any record of success
then the plans and projects announced
offer the prospect of continued additions
to the commercial, residential and recrea-
tional resources for Baltimore. The follow-
ing are projects planned or underway.

Camden Yards — On the western
boundary of the Inner Harbor projet area
are 22 acres of land including the Camden
Station owned by the CSX System. This
property lies to the immediate west of
Otterbein and is proposed for residences, a
hotel and offices. The first phase —the new
Federal Reserve Bank Building was com-
pleted in November, 1982.

Pratt at Calvert Street — In early 1982
the Rouse Company won the right to

. develop a $190-million hotel/retail/office/

parking eomplex on the vacant lot imme-
diately north of Harborplace along Pratt
Street Boulevard. The Rouse Company has
announced that the Westin Hotel chain will
operate a 550 room hotel. Included in the
complex will be over 600,000 sq. ft. of
commercial space and offices, and a 1200
parking garage.

Pier 4 Power Plant — At the end of
1982 the Six Flags Corporation was selected
by the City to turn the former power plant
on Pier 4 into a family entertainment cen-
ter. The estimated cost of this project is $26
million. Work began on the building in the
fall of 1983.

Light Street High-Rise — The Murdock
Development Corp. has begun the con-
struction of a tower with 165 condomini-
ums and a luxury hotel with parking and
commercial space on the vacant land south
of McCormick’s spice plant on Light Street.

Piers 5 and 6 and the Lower Jones Falls
— Piers 5 and 6 and the east bank of the
Jones Falls present a major new opportun-
ity for continuing the expansion of the
Inner Harbor and are now undergoing in-
tensive planning study. Proposals for this
area include continuing the public walkway
around the entire perimeter of the shore-
line, tying in with the walkways now in
place across piers 3 to 6 and the Inner Har-
bor promenade; installation of marinas;
and public plazas with a dramatic view
across the water to the downtown’s skyline
and harbor ‘activities.

Beyond the Falls Harbor/Little Italy
area is Fells Point where private renovation
is taking place. Ultimately this historic
waterfront neighborhood will be tied to
the Inner Harbor by means of a pedestrian
walkway along the harbor’s edge and rede-
velopment of the intervening land area.

“The Brokerage” — To the north of
the harbor along the Jones Falls, “The
Brokerage” is under development. This $28
million project is being undertaken by a
private developer who is renovating an
entire block of derelict commercial build-
ings for shops and offices, building a ga-
rage and new office space and constructing
a market pavilion in the historic Fish Market
Square.

The excitement that the Inner Harbor
redevelopment has engendered, in Balti-
more, throughout the United States, and in
all parts of the world, is hardly over. The
projects described above and those on the
drawing boards and in prospect make it
obvious Baltimore is not through showing
what can be done with a prime waterfront
location.

In 1963 a friend is said to have told
Mayor McKeldin about his trip to Stock-
holm and what splendid use that city made
of its waterfront. Today delegations from
far corners of the world visit Baltimore to
take back th&lessons of the Inner Harbor’s
success.



87
